Award.AwardTitle: SITE Summer Workshop in Theoretical Economics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award continues NSF support for the Stanford Institute of Theoretical Economics (SITE) Summer Workshops. This collection of workshops brings together prominent scholars with promising young economists for discussions of research in progress. The workshops attract an international audience and provide a way to initiate new research collaborations. Topics are drawn each year from a list of cutting-edge research areas, interdisciplinary workshops such as Economics and Psychology, and workshops on new methods for data analysis linked to economic theory.

Broader impacts include the contribution to the training of graduate students and young scholars who attend and participate, the workshop website that makes the presented papers available to a broad audience, and the interdisciplinary focus of several of the workshop sessions. The workshop makes a true contribution to US leadership in this area of science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supports a series of workshops focused on topics of theoretical economics. The series includes 8 to 10 workshops annually, running for two or three days each. Workshops are comprised of presentations of in-progress work by economists from institutions around the US and world, with opportunities for discussion and critique. In 2016, the Stanford Institute for Theoretical Economics (SITE) included 11 two- or three-day sessions, 166 presentations, and 650 attendees. Session organizers are enlisted from across a variety of institutions. Organizers selected papers for presentation through a competitive process that in 2016 included 546 submissions. Organizers prioritize choosing presenters from a wide variety of institutions and those who are beginning their careers.

Stanford University has hosted this series of summer workshops in economic theory since 1969. SITE plays a vital role in economic theory development, serving as a renowned forum that attracts top scholars from around the world and bringing together theorists as well as applied economists with an active interest in the theoretical foundations of their work.

SITE gives leading senior investigators, emerging scholars, and students the opportunity to share their research results. The workshop environment promotes interaction, stimulates discussion, and encourages collaboration, leading to research on new topics as well as to new applications of economic theory. SITE’s support of younger and underrepresented scholars promotes their professional development with the opportunity to present and receive feedback on their work, and engage with participants from peers to senior scholars. SITE attracts an international and interdisciplinary audience providing an opportunity for diverse scholars to learn from one another and explore questions in other fields. And if history is a guide, many of this year’s presenters will successfully submit their research papers to refereed journals for publication.

SITE benefits greatly from continued support from the National Science Foundation to conduct the workshops and to include a broad, diverse group of participants. NSF funding helps pay conference expenses as well as helping younger and less established scholars with travel costs.

2016 session topics included Institutions and Economic Impacts of International Trade Policy; New Models of Financial Markets; and The Macroeconomics of Uncertainty and Volatility, among many others. Summaries and programs from each past workshop as well as drafts of some presented papers can be found at https://site.stanford.edu/.
